definition: This ontology contain what was formally known as BIRNLex-CogSenseBehavior version 1.3.1. -- The BIRN Project lexicon will provide entities for data and database annotation for the BIRN project, covering anatomy, disease, data collection, project management and experimental design.  It is built using the organizational framework provided by the foundational Basic Formal Ontology (BFO).  It uses an abstract biomedical layer on top of that - OBO-UBO which has been constructed  as a proposal to the OBO Foundry.  This is meant to support creating a sharable view of core biomedical objects such as biomaterial_entity, and organismal_entity that all biomedical ontologies are likely to need and want to use with the same intended meaning.  The BIRNLex-Main.owl ontology imports the several domain specific ontology modues required to construct a formal ontology for the multiscale investigation of neurological disease.  This particular module contains entities related to the behavior and cognitive capabilities and actions of organisms (BB:2007-03-05).
id_space: rdfs http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#; snap http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/snap#; ro http://www.obofoundry.org/ro/ro.owl#; span http://www.ifomis.org/bfo/1.1/span#; protege http://protege.stanford.edu/plugins/owl/protege#; rdf http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#; BIRNLex_annotation_properties http://ontology.neuinfo.org/NIF/Backend/BIRNLex_annotation_properties.owl#; OBO_annotation_properties http://ontology.neuinfo.org/NIF/Backend/OBO_annotation_properties.owl#; owl http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#; dc http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/; NIF-Function http://ontology.neuinfo.org/NIF/Function/NIF-Function.owl#; xsd http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#; skos http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#
editorialNote: The current (2006-10-10) members of the BIRN Ontology Task Force are listed here as the primary curators of the main BIRNLex ontology.  Others from within BIRN labs and directly collaborating with BIRN labs have also contributed to specific classes and class properties.  Effort is made to provide attribution for each class, where appropriate.; next ID: birnlex_15000; ID use: 1800 - 1914; 2500 - 2512
title: NIF-Function (formerlly BIRNLex-CogBehavior)
changeNote: Processed file with XSLT to remove the explicit DataTypeProperty declarations (v1.2.2); Now using a specific set of AnnotationProperties that link to specific Enumeration classes to specify annotations from a fixed list of values - e.g., ExternalSource, DefinitionSource.  This is the second iteration of this mechanism (first was put in v1.2.2).  This second version follows a patter recommended by Alan Ruttenberg which avoids using ObjectProperties as the Manchester design pattern for Value Partitions recommends, and instead sticks to AnnotationProperties only.  Note this version of OBO_annotation_properties uses the same EnumerationClasses from v1.2.2, and still includes the related ObjectProperties, so as to be able to support XSLT-based translation of the BIRNLex files that used the v1.2.2 pattern.  The next version of this file will eliminate the ObjectProperties and will rename the equivalent AnnotationProperties to remove the trailing '2' put in there to provide a unique name.; Have 'cleansed' the file to be OWL-DL (v1.2.2).; Filled out and reconciled the sensory sensation and transduction classes, collating them against UMLS, MeSH, and GO - also adding external IDs for each of those sources.; Adjusted some disjoints and restrictions, so the the ontology would pass Pellet consistency tests. Adjusted mereological relaions for certain types of memory to link them to appropriate sensory perceptions and behavioral activties (BB: 2007-10-04).; v1.3.0 (2007-08-18) - Changed many things, but primarily: (1) removed rdf:datatype xsd:string specs for all AnnotationProperties, since they are now all untyped and should assume STRING as a the default; (2) added the typing of AnnotationProperties using annotationType which should aid in algorithmically processing; (3) Also updated the XSLT BIRNLex cleanser to clean up more Protege mangling and provide a fixed order for certain properties.  This last tool is brittle, as it probably will require continued maintenance to handle more complex OWL constructs than we know have in the file - especially highly nested constructs using class axioms; (4) added use of hasReferenceURLTemplate for linking IDs; (5) Added many more concepts to cover NIF and other BIRN requirements.
subject: The BIRN project lexicon+ontology
contributor: Amarnath Gupta; Maryann Martone; Bill Bug; Jeff Grethe; Jessica Turner; Christine Fennema-Notestine; David Kennedy; Carol Bean
creator: The BIRN Ontology Task Force

name: Sensory stimulus transduction
editorialNote: * The series of events during sensory perception in which a sensory stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal. [GO:ai, MGI:dph] (GO)

name: Mechanical stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events in which a sensory mechanical stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal. [GO:ai] (GO)

name: Chemical stimulus transduction
definition: * The series of events in which a sensory chemical stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal. [GO:ai] (GO)
synonym: sensory detection of chemical stimulus; Molecule binding stimulus transduction

name: Light stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events in which a sensory light stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal. [GO:ai] (GO)

name: Temperature stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events in which a sensory temperature stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal. [GO:ai] (GO)

name: Generative memory activity
editorialNote: This may not be the optimal asserted classification for these extensions  (BB:2008-03-13).
birnlexDefinition: A behavioral activity which when expressed entails the generation and use of stored memories (BB:2008-03-13).

name: Gustatory stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events in which a sensory chemical stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal. [GO:ai] (GO)
synonym: taste stimulus transduction; sensory detection of gustatory stimulus; sensory detection of taste stimulus

name: Olfactory stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events in which a sensory chemical stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal. [GO:ai] (GO)
synonym: sensory detection of smell stimulus; sensory detection of olfactory stimulus; smell stimulus transduction

name: Bicarbonate stimulus transduction
definition: A sensory transduction event whereby chemoreceptors in the carotid body of higher mammals detect the amount of plasma bicarbonate communicating this signal to medullary neurons involved in control of respiratory rate.  Higher pH derives primarily from higher plasma pCO2.  The medullary neurons increase respiratory rate in response to a rise in pH, so as to vent more CO2 and thereby decrease pH back toward neutral (BB: 2008-03-13)

name: Molecule flow stimulus transduction
definition: This is a stimulus where the flow of a specific molecular species is the direct event being detected

name: Pressure stimulus transduction
definition: This is a stimulus where the the direct physical property being sensed is the local pressure, such as with the baroreceptors in the the aortic arch and carotid sinuses of higher mammals.

name: Touch stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events involved in the perception of touch in which a sensory mechanical stimulus is received by a cell and converted into a molecular signal.

name: Echolocation sensation
definition: * An auditory orientation mechanism involving the emission of high frequency sounds which are reflected back to the emitter (animal). (MSH)
synonym: perception of environment using reflected sound waves; echo location

name: Sound sensation
definition: The series of events in which a sensory chemical stimulus is converted into a percieved senstation. (BB:2008-03-13)
synonym: sound perception; sensory detection of sound stimulus; sensory detection of olfactory stimulus

name: Heat sensation
definition: The series of events in which a sensory heat stimulus is converted into a percieved senstation. (BB:2008-03-13)

name: Cold sensation
definition: The series of events in which a sensory cold stimulus is converted into a percieved senstation. (BB:2008-03-13)

name: Ciliary displacement stimulus transduction
definition: Energy transfer between some physical force and primary sensory cilia displacement which to stimulation of the neurons (BB: 2008-03-13)

name: Accelleration stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events involved in equilibrioception in which a sensory mechanical stimulus is received by a cell and converted into a molecular signal. During equilibrioception, mechanical stimuli may be in the form of input from pressure receptors or from the labyrinth system of the inner ears.
synonym: equilibrioception, sensory transduction of mechanical stimulus

name: Electroception stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events during electroception in which a sensory electrical stimulus is received by a cell and converted into a molecular signal.

name: Magnetic field stimulus transduction
definition: The series of events involved in magnetoception in which a sensory mechanical stimulus is received by a cell and converted into a molecular signal. The stimulus is in the form of torque on particles such as magnetite which respond to a magnetic field.
synonym: magnetoception, sensory transduction of mechanical stimulus

name: Solid object-coupled ciliary displacement stimulus transduction
definition: Energy transfer between some physical force and a solid object which is coupled to primary sensory cilia and whose displacement leads to stimulation of the neurons (BB: 2008-03-13)
prefLabel: Solid object-coupled ciliary displacement stimulus transduction

name: Fluid-coupled ciliary displacement stimulus transduction
definition: Energy transfer between some physical force and a solid object which is coupled to primary sensory cilia and whose displacement leads to stimulation of the neurons (BB: 2008-03-13)
example: endolymph-based displacement of cochlear hair cell cilia in the mammalian ear.

name: Musculoskeletal equilibrium sensation
synonym: postural balance sense; postural equilibrium sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: A state of the body being evenly balanced in POSTURE. The biomechanical responses of the MUSCULOSKELETAL SYSTEM during standing, walking, sitting, and other movements.

name: Memory-driven activity
editorialNote: This may not be the optimal asserted classification for these extensions  (BB:2008-03-13).
birnlexDefinition: A behavioral activity which when expressed entails the generation and/or use of stored memories (BB:2008-03-13).

name: Cognitive process
editorialNote: Note that we are distinguishing between processes and functions, so there will appear to be a set of duplicate classes.  The distinction as described by BFO, as we understand it, is that functions are end-directed activities of continuants.  So memory function is an end activity of a memory process.  We therefore measure memory function as an indicator of the effectiveness of the memory process.
externallySourcedDefinition: * Conceptual functions or thinking in all its forms. (MSH)

name: Touch sensation
synonym: Tactile perception; Touch perception; Tactile sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: * Awareness of the qualities or characteristics of objects, substances, or surfaces by means of touch. (PSY)

name: Temperature sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: * The sensation of cold, heat, coolness, and warmth. (MSH)

name: Free recall
birnlexDefinition: The cognitive process of remembering/recollecting previously learned material without aid of any external cues.

name: Discrimination activity
externallySourcedDefinition: * Ability to distinguish between examples vs nonexamples of a concept, based on the presence or absence of its defining attributes. (PSY)
usageNote: Note you could create a more specific type of discrimination activity - e.g., 2 point discrimination - by declaring it as a type and specifying it has_integral_part SOME Visual Perception (BB).

name: Cognitive state
editorialNote: Describes entities related to cognitive processes.  At some point, this will have to be merged with the OBR but for now I think it's best kept separate (MM).
changeNote: Moved from base of hiearchy to a subclass of bfo:realizable_entity (BB).; Moved under bfo:Disposition, as these are states toward which the organisms in which they inhere are disposed (BB:2007-03-05).

name: Iconic memory
externallySourcedDefinition: Brief sensory memory, usually lasting only fractions of a second. (PSY)
scopeNote: How would this entity related to short-term and long-term memory (BB).

name: Pain sensation
definition: An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli and generally received by specialized nerve endings (MeSH).
synonym: Pain perception; Ache; Pain; Physical suffering; Nociception
externallySourcedDefinition: * The series of events required for an organism to receive a painful stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal. Pain is medically defined as the physical sensation of discomfort or distress caused by injury or illness, so can hence be described as a harmful stimulus which signals current (or impending) tissue damage. Pain may come from extremes of temperature, mechanical damage, electricity or from noxious chemical substances. [http://www.onelook.com/] (GO)
usageNote: MeSH includes the following qualified subtypes based on the nature of the pain experienced: Burning Pain; Crushing Pain; Migratory Pain; Radiating Pain; Splitting Pain
definingCitation: Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p45

name: Emotion
birnlexDefinition: A mental state that arises spontaneously rather than through conscious effort and is often accompanied by physiological changes; a feeling.
externallySourcedDefinition: * Conceptually broad term referring to the affective aspects of human consciousness. Use a more specific term if possible. Use ANIMAL EMOTIONALITY for nonhuman subjects. (PSY)

name: Memory consolidation
scopeNote: As opposed to simple storage and recall (BB).

name: Locomotor function
tempDefinition: A behavioral function enabling an entity to alter its location under the power of its own motive force (BB:2007-03-05).

name: Semantic memory
externallySourcedDefinition: Organized knowledge about words, their meanings, and their relations. (PSY)

name: Bitter taste sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required to receive a bitter taste stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal.

name: Behavioral system function
tempDefinition: Behavioral system functions consist of the variety of emergent operations for which the organism's nervous system is the primary enabling organ system and as such behavioral system functions can be said to inhere in the nervous system.  Behavioral functions may lead to action via a physiological actuation system such as the skeleto-muscular system or give rise to actions only percieved internally by the individual in which the function inheres (BB).

name: Somatic sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: consciousness of having a body. (CSP)

name: Happiness
birnlexDefinition: Highly pleasant emotion characterized by outward manifestations of gratification; joy

name: Electrical sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required for an organism to receive a sensory electrical stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal.

name: Sensory perception
editorialNote: The disposition to perceive sensory stimuli is used within BIRNLex to fully define the context for stimulus-triggered behavioral or neurophysiological activity, such as stimulus-triggered functional imaging studies.  They will also be used to specify the type of sensory system a stimuli given in a protocol is designed to affect (BB).

name: Behavioral activity
editorialNote: This seems a bit contrived but appears to be an appropriate way to classify the sub-classes of behavioral activity derived from this class.  These certainly are dispositions inhering in the entity performing the activity.  There are also many behavioral activities where it really is a non-sequetor to call them behavioral functions - e.g., 'smoking' is certainly a behavior, but it really makes little sense to represent a 'smoking function' and underlying 'smoking process.' Describing behavior as an activity to which an entity is disposed makes it possible to represent very complex behaviors for which the corresponding behavioral function(s) and underlying process(es) are not yet characterized.  Note also that one can describe the activity without proscribing the associated function and underlying process - e.g., ants and humans can both be said to be disposed toward expressing 'locomotive behavior', and, yet, the associated 'locomotor function' and underlying 'locomotor process' in each organism is very different.  Note also that behavior in general is not restricted to organic 'living' entities but can also be expressed by 'non-living' entities such as the old 'bobbing bird' toy or an automatic loom.  Specific entities may have specific dispositions for expressing certain sets of behavioral activities (BB:2007-03-05).
changeNote: The has_integral_part restriction can be used to define complex activities that include a specific sensory component, such as a stimulus-triggered type of activity, where the stimulus targets one or more sensory modalities This restriction is not required or defining, but it declares what other continuants can be associated with a type of behavioral activity to create more complex activities.  Right now, that is limited to sensory perception associated with a particular sensory stimulus.  It's possible this is not quite the right type of obo_ro mereological relation, but it seemed like an appropriate start.  When a sensory perception is involved in an activity, it would be hard to refer to that disposition as a proper_part, though possibly this should just fall back to the more generic obo_ro:part_of (BB).
externallySourcedDefinition: * Behavior; the actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli. (NCI)
usageNote: These descriptions of activity are intended to be used to represent behavior at the level of organism, typically engaging complex brain circuitry, multple brain regions, and complex effector systems.  It is not intended for descriptions of single cell activity.
tempDefinition: Overt activity inhering in the action of instantiating a behavioral function.  In other words, the expressed activity resulting from the action of the behavioral process which makes up a given behavioral function (BB: 2007-03-05).

name: Visceral sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required for an organism to receive a sensory temperature stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal.

name: Verbal memory
usageNote: How does this related to Verbal behavioral function? Possibly not at all - really need a definition to know (BB).

name: Anxiety
externallySourcedDefinition: Persistent feeling of dread, apprehension, and impending disaster (MeSH).

name: Auditory sensation
synonym: hearing; audition; auditory perception; hearing sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: * The auditory faculty, the perception of sound by the ear. (NCI)

id: birnlex_1833;//cancerweb.ncl.ac.uk/, http://www.onelook.com/, ISBN:0582227089] (GO); acquisition, retention, recall, and recognition. (CSP)
name: Memory Process
birnlexDefinition: The cognitive process of encoding, storing and retrieving past experience
externallySourcedDefinition: * Complex mental function having four distinct phases: (1) memorizing or learning, (2) retention, (3) recall, and (4) recognition. Clinically, it is usually subdivided into immediate, recent, and remote memory. (MSH)

name: Smoking
externallySourcedDefinition: The act of puffing and/or inhaling smoke from a lit cigarette, cigar, or pipe. (NCI)

name: Visual memory
usageNote: How does this related to Visual perception? Possibly not at all - really need a definition to know (BB).

name: Fast pain sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required for an organism to receive a fast pain stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal. Fast pain is often subjectively described as a sharp or stabbing pain; in humans, the signals from a fast pain stimulus are perceived and relayed along myelinated A-delta fibers to the central nervous system, reaching their target in about 0.1 seconds. [http://www.spine-health.com/]

name: Fear
externallySourcedDefinition: The affective response to an actual current external danger which subsides with the elimination of the threatening condition. (MeSH); Unpleasant but normal emotional response to genuine external danger or threats; compare with ANXIETY and CLINICAL ANXIETY. (CSP)

name: Anger
externallySourcedDefinition: A strong emotional feeling of displeasure aroused by being interfered with, injured or threatened (MeSH).

name: Attention
externallySourcedDefinition: The process of focusing on certain aspects of current experience to the exclusion of others. It is the act of heeding or taking notice or concentrating. (MeSH)

name: Olfactory sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: * Smell; the faculty of smell, the sensation that results when olfactory receptors in the nose are stimulated by particular chemicals in gaseous form. (NCI)

name: Moral reasoning activity
tempDefinition: Moral reasoning is individual or collective practical reasoning about what, morally, one ought to do (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosphy).

name: Lateralized activity
editorialNote: Laterality may actually be most effectively expressed as a measured quality via PATO (BB:2007-03-05).
birnlexDefinition: A behavioral activity expressing a behavioral function that is differentially supported across the two cerebrain hemispheres in the vertebrate brain (BB:2007-03-05).

name: Sadness
editorialNote: In what way is this related to Happiness?  Is there in fact a single underlying Cognitive_entity for which Happiness and Sadness are just either end of the quality gamut describing that entity as experienced by an individual (BB)?  Can you experience both Happiness and Sadness simultaneously (BB)?

name: Autobiographical memory
birnlexDefinition: Memory that involves the conscious recall or recognition of one's own life.

name: Inductive reasoning activity
tempDefinition: inductive reasoning is a type of reasoning in which the premises of an argument are believed to support the conclusion but do not ensure it. It is used to ascribe properties or relations to types based on tokens (i.e., on one or a small number of observations or experiences); or to formulate laws based on limited observations of recurring phenomenal patterns. Induction is used, for example, in USING SPECIFIC PROPOSITIONS such as:'this ice is cold'; 'a billiard ball moves when struck with a cue' TO INFER GENERAL PROPOSITIONS such as:'all ice is cold'; 'all billiard balls struck with a cue move.' In other words, inductive reasoning infers probable antecedents as a result of observing multiple consequents - i.e., inferring some 'b' from multiple instantiations of 'a' when 'b' entails 'a'.. (Wikipedia - BB:2007-03-05).

name: Working memory
birnlexDefinition: Memory that involves the conscious encoding, storing and retrieving information encountered recently

name: Recognition memory
externallySourcedDefinition: The memory that someone or something present has been previously encountered. (MeSH)

name: Motor activity
externallySourcedDefinition: * Any form of exercise or movement. Physical activity may include planned activity such as walking, running, basketball, or other sports. Physical activity may also include other daily activities such as household chores, yard work, walking the dog, etc. (from NIDDK Glossary; http://www.niddk.nih.gov/health/nutrit/pubs/glossary/glossaryintro.htm) (NCI)

name: Slow pain sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required for an organism to receive a slow pain stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal. Slow pain is often subjectively described as an aching or throbbing pain; in humans, the signals from a slow pain stimulus are perceived and relayed along unmyelinated C fibers to the central nervous system, reaching their target in about 1 second. Slow pain is often associated with tissue destruction. [http://www.people.vcu.edu/~mikuleck/ssspain/, http://www.spine-health.com/]

name: Cognitive function
editorialNote: The examples are derived from the Wikipedia page on 'Mental function.'  Perhaps a more narrow set of examples that specifically fit to our requirements in BIRN would be more appropriate.  A more authoritative neuropsychological source should also be used, as some of these examples may be considered by neuropsychologists to be degenerate - e.g., 'belief function' is_a 'imaginative function' (BB:2007-03-05).; Note that we are distinguishing between processes and functions, so there will appear to be a set of duplicate classes.  The distinction as described by BFO, as we understand it, is that functions are end-directed activities of continuants.  So memory function is an end activity of a memory process.  We therefore measure memory function as an indicator of the effectiveness of the memory process.
example: conceptual function; volitional function; creative function; introspective function; imaginative function; emotional function; belief function; perceptual function; reasoning function; memory function
externallySourcedDefinition: * Level of functioning in intellectual tasks. (PSY)
scopeNote: A specific instance of engaging a cognitive function leads to the creation of a mental event distinct from the cognitive functional process itself. The event of perceiving something, for instance, is different from the perceptual process in its entirety, the overall ability to perceive things. In other words, an instance of perceiving is different from the cognitive function that makes it possible (BB:2007-03-05 - derived from Wikipedia).
tempDefinition: Cognitive functions are a type of behavioral function giving rise to actions only percieved internally by the individual in which the function inheres, though this internal perception may ultimately give rise to an externalized action (BB).

name: Salty taste sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required to receive a salty taste stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal.

name: Verbal activity
birnlexDefinition: A behavioral activity employing verbal function to either generate or interpreting meaningful spoken or writen words or symbols.  If generating verbal output, a motor system is invoked.  If interpreting verbal input, typically a sensory system is invoked, though certain interpretive activity involves movement of the sensory organ - e.g., eye movements during reading (BB:2007-03-05).
externallySourcedDefinition: * Includes both producing and responding to words, either written or spoken. (MSH)

name: Sour taste sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required to receive a sour taste stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal.

name: Memory function
editorialNote: Note the has_integral_part restriction helps to support the variety of memory types - e.g., verbal memory, motor memory, sense memory, etc..  It isn't truly correct to say a memory instance includes a behavioral activity as an integral part.  It would be more correct to say a memory instance (measured through some assessment technique) ENCODES or somehow includes a link to a particular behavioral activity (BB).

name: Memory
editorialNote: The has_integral_part restriction can be used to create very specific Memory extensions based on the sensation(s) and activity(s) the memory entails (BB).; These are problematic and imply a certain amount of multiple inheritance - e.g., there can be an instance of a memory that is both a Remote memory and an Autobiographical memory.  Trying to cover the distinct types of memory covered in UMLS mostly derived from PsychInfo (BB).
scopeNote: Need to develop a means of using ObjectProperties to define short-term and long-term memory.

name: Sweet taste sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required to receive a sweet taste stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal.

name: Autobiographical memory
birnlexDefinition: Memory that involves the conscious recall or recognition of ones own life.

name: Feeding
comment: I'm not sure that the examples given were consistent with the synonym eating". Rather
is_a: these activities are part of and activity that is "feeding/eating". So I deleted them. I would also favor moving "feeding" to the preferred label and getting rid of "appetitive activity". (Maryann Martone)"
definition: birnlex_1827
gene_Ontology_ID: A behavioral activity expressed while ingesting food.

name: Umami taste sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required to receive an umami taste stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal. Umami taste is the savory taste of meats and other foods that are rich in glutamates.

name: Skeletomotor reflex activity
tempDefinition: A behavioral activity expressing immediate sensory-motor integration through activation of muscular-driven process (BB:2007-03-05).

name: Working memory
birnlexDefinition: Memory that involves the conscious encoding, storing and retrieving information encountered recently
scopeNote: How would this entity related to short-term and long-term memory (BB).

name: Appetitive function
tempDefinition: A behavioral function supporting the process of ingesting food.

name: Chemical sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required for an organism to receive a sensory chemical stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal.

name: Photo sensation
synonym: sensory transduction of light stimulus; Photo perception
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events in which a sensory light stimulus is received and converted into a molecular signal.

name: Locomotor activity
externallySourcedDefinition: * Movement or the ability to move from one place or another. It can refer to humans, vertebrate or invertebrate animals, and microorganisms. (MSH)

name: Abductive reasoning activity
tempDefinition: Abductive reasoning is a type of reasoning in which a hypothesis is chosen to best explain the relevant evidence - also called 'inference to the best explanation'. Abduction starts from a set of accepted facts and infers to their most likely, or best, explanations. The term abduction is also sometimes used to just mean the generation of hypotheses to explain observations or conclusions. Abductive reasoning allows inferring 'a' as an explanation of 'b'. Because of this, abduction allows the precondition 'a' of 'a entails b' to be inferred from the consequence, and, as such, such abduction is formally equivalent to the logical fallacy 'affirming the consequent.' (Wikipedia - BB:2007-03-05).

name: Skeletomotor reflex function
tempDefinition: A behavioral function supporting immediate sensory-motor integration with minimal nervous system processing (BB:2007-03-05).

name: Proprioception
externallySourcedDefinition: * The mechanism involved in the self-regulation of posture and movement through stimuli originating in the receptors imbedded in the joints, tendons, muscles, and labyrinth. (MSH)

name: Explicit memory
externallySourcedDefinition: Memory of events where one is also aware of learning or experiencing the event. (PSY)

name: Magnetic sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required for an organism to receive a stimulus relating to a magnetic field, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal. Stimuli may be chemical, mechanical or electrical and interpreting these stimuli allows an organism to determine the orientation of a magnetic field. Magnetoreception also involves the perception of light; birds cannot orient without the presence of short wavelength (blue/green) light

name: Equilibrioception sensation
synonym: Equilibrioception perception; Orientation relative to gravity sensation; Orientation relative to gravity perception
externallySourcedDefinition: The series of events required for an organism to receive an orientational stimulus, convert it to a molecular signal, and recognize and characterize the signal. Equilibrioception refers to a combination of processes by which an organism can perceive its orientation with respect to gravity. In animals, stimuli come from labyrinth system of the inner ears, monitoring the direction of motion; visual stimuli, with information on orientation and motion; pressure receptors, which tell the organism which body surfaces are in contact with the ground; and proprioceptive cues, which report which parts of the body are in motion. [http://www.medterms.com, http://www.onelook.com/]

name: Implicit memory
externallySourcedDefinition: Memory of events without specific awareness of learning or experiencing the event. (PSY)

name: Nutrition function
externallySourcedDefinition: Nourishment of the body with balanced food in a manner that energy, maintenance, and growth processes occur. (OMS)

name: Visual sensation
synonym: sight; vision; Visual perception; sense of sight
externallySourcedDefinition: * Sight; the faculty of vision, the perception of objects by the eye. (NCI)

name: Deductive reasoning activity
tempDefinition: Deductive reasoning is a type of reasoning in which the conclusion is necessitated by, or reached from, previously known facts (the premises). If the premises are true, the conclusion must be true. In deductive reasoning, the conclusion is dependent on its premises. That is, a false premise can possibly lead to a false conclusion, and inconclusive premises will also yield an inconclusive conclusion (Wikipedia - BB:2007-03-05).

name: Taste sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: * Taste; the faculty of taste, distinguishing substances by means of the taste buds. (NCI)

name: Saccadic eye movement
tempDefinition: Rapid eye movement relative to an initial target

name: Eidetic memory
externallySourcedDefinition: * A visual image which is recalled in accurate detail. It is a sort of projection of an image on a mental screen. (MSH)

name: Sensory system function
tempDefinition: Sensory system functions consist of the variety of capabilities for transducing external stimuli into internal receptive signals for which the organism's nervous system is the primary enabling organ system.  As such sensory functions can be said to inhere in the nervous system.  Sensory system functions usual lead through the action of complex nervous system circuitry to higher level cognitive perception such as a visual image, a smell, a taste, etc.

name: Nervous system function
tempDefinition: These are parts of nervous system function - i.e., functional components which inhere in some portion of the nervous system.

name: Auditory system function
editorialNote: Though the CSP definition given refers to a process (which will exist separately in BIRNLex as an occurent), this is the closest definition that captures the sense of a function part of the nervous system.   The several other definitions relate more specifically only to the direct sensation component of overall auditory system function.
externallySourcedDefinition: process whereby auditory stimuli are selected, organized and interpreted by the organism. (CSP)

name: Kinesthetic sensation
externallySourcedDefinition: The sense of body position and movement, mediated by peripheral receptors in the muscles and elsewhere (limb and joint position) (CSP)

name: Kinesthetic system function
externallySourcedDefinition: Provides for the sense of body position and movement (limb and joint position). (CSP)

name: Gustatory system function
editorialNote: Though the definition given refers to a disposition toward sensing and processing (which will exist separately in BIRNLex as an occurent), this is the closest definition that captures the sense of a function part of the nervous system.   The several other definitions relate more specifically only to the direct sensation component of overall auditory system function.
externallySourcedDefinition: * Taste; the faculty of taste, distinguishing substances by means of the taste buds. (NCI)

name: Consciousness
definition: Sense of awareness of self and of the environment.(NCI)

name: Executive function
definition: A cognitive function that controls and regulates other abilities and behaviors. Executive functions include the ability to initiate and stop actions, to monitor and change behavior as needed, and to plan future behavior when faced with novel tasks and situations. Executive functions allow us to anticipate outcomes and adapt to changing situations. The ability to form concepts and think abstractly are often considered components of executive function.
